Original sentence: The following research studies have investigated the relationship between sleep and cognitive function in individuals with traumatic brain injury (TBI). These studies have shown that sleep disturbances are common among individuals with TBI, with approximately 70% of participants reporting sleep problems. Furthermore, research has found that sleep disturbances are associated with poorer cognitive function in individuals with TBI. Specifically, sleep disturbances have been linked to deficits in attention, memory, and executive functioning. In addition, some studies have reported that sleep disturbances are more severe in individuals with moderate to severe TBI compared to those with mild TBI. Therefore, it is essential to investigate the relationship between sleep and cognitive function in individuals with TBI to better understand the underlying mechanisms and to develop effective interventions.
